name: transport, freight train, diesel | transport, freight train | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21836/documentation

This dataset represents the transport of one metric ton.km of freight in South Africa by a diesel locomotive. The dataset represents the entire transport life cycle, including the production and maintenance of the locomotive, production and maintenance of the goods wagons, the transportation of goods and the construction, operation, maintenance and disposal of railway track. The scope of this dataset is the operation of the locomotive, which has inputs of locomotive and goods wagon, maintenance (goods wagon and locomotive) and railway track via linking to global datasets, i.e. the infrastructure and maintenance datasets are not South African-specific.;Diesel consumption includes shunting and is calculated from total freight rail diesel usage (Transnet, 2017a) and total metric ton.kms transported using diesel locomotives (19% of total tonne.kms). The total metric ton.kms transported by diesel locomotives is calculated using the fuel efficiency (Transnet, 2017a) and the total tonne.kms of rail freight for 2017. Total metric ton.kms for general rail freight is reported directly (Transnet, 2017b), while metric ton.kms for iron ore and coal exports are calculated from the total tonnages transported (Transnet, 2017b) and the average transport distances. Transport distance is averaged for 2009, 2010 and 2011 for iron ore exports, and modelled by linear regression of 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2016 data for coal exports (Transnet, 2016a; Transnet, 2011; Transnet, 2010). The diesel usage reported by Transnet is the total diesel use (including shunting). Thus the diesel use by diesel freight trains (including shunting) is taken to be the total diesel use reported by Transnet less an estimate of the diesel used for shunting electric locomotives. Diesel use for shunting is estimated at 19% of total diesel use (personal communication with Transnet), with the share of diesel use for shunting electric locomotives apportioned on the basis of metric ton.kms transported by electric locomotives (81% of total metric ton.kms). These figures represent all rail freight movements in South Africa. ;Emissions of particulates, nitrogen oxides (NOx) and non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOC) are calculated using emission factors from EcoTransIT (2016). South African locomotives are split into UIC I and UIC II emission classes based on the current locomotive fleet (Transnet, 2016b), with the assumption that only the new Class 43 diesel locomotives met UIC II emission standards (TransportWorldAfrica, 2012). The partitioning of particulate emissions into size classes is according to Spielmann et al. (2007). Sulphur dioxide (SO2) emissions are calculated from the sulphur content in local diesel (500 ppm (SAPIA, 2015)) and the assumption that all sulphur is emitted as sulphur dioxide. All other emissions to air are extrapolated on the basis of diesel consumption from the global dataset ("transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004"), with the global dataset derived from data primarily of Swiss/European orgin, described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007). ;Locomotive production and maintenance are described in the individual global datasets. Locomotive demand per metric ton.km is calculated from the number of diesel freight locomotives (Transnet, 2016b) and the total metric ton.kms of freight transported by diesel locomotives (see above explanation on how this is calculated). A locomotive lifespan of 40 years is assumed (Spielmann et al., 2007). Goods wagon production and maintenance are described in the individual global datasets. Goods wagon demand per metric ton.km is calculated from the number of goods wagons (Transnet, 2016b) and the total metric ton.kms of freight moved annually by diesel locomotives (calculated as described above). A goods wagon lifespan of 40 years is assumed (Spielmann et al., 2007). The construction, operation, maintenance and disposal of railway track is described in the global dataset. Railway track demand per metric ton.km is calculated from the total length of two-way railway track (Transnet, 2016a), and the total metric ton.kms of diesel freight rail transport (calculated as described above).    ;References:;Transnet (2017a) Transnet Sustainability Report 2017;      ;Transnet (2017b) Transnet Integrated Report 2017;                                                                                                                                                                               Transnet (2016a); Transnet Long Term Planning Framework 2016 - Freight Demand Plan;                                                                                                                     Transnet (2016b) Transnet Long Term Planning Framework - Rail Development Plan;                                                                                                                             Transnet (2011) Integrated Annual Report 2011;                                                                                                                                                                                     Transnet (2010) Integrated Annual Report 2010;;Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.;                                                       EcoTransIT (2016) Ecological Transport Information Tool for Worldwide Transports - Methodology and Data Update;                                                                                SAPIA (2015) Cleaner Fuels II Available at: http://www.sapia.org.za/key-issues/cleaner-fuels-ii;                                                                                          TransportWorldAfrica (2012) GE Transportation & MIC deliver reliable locomotives with high local content on-time. Available at: http://www.transportworldafrica.co.za/2012/06/28/ge-transportation-mic-deliver-reliable-locomotives-with-high-local-content-on-time/ (22 May 2018).

The scope of this dataset is the operation of the locomotive and wagon train, with inputs of locomotives, goods wagons and railway track (covering their production, maintenance and disposal). The transportation service starts with the demand for diesel and the construction of locomotive, goods wagons and track. 

The dataset ends with the service of transporting freight 1 metric ton.km. . The dataset covers the operation of a diesel locomotive, and includes the consumption of diesel and the associated emissions to air. The dataset calls global datasets on the production and maintenance of a locomotive and goods wagon, as well as the construction, operation, maintenance and disposal of railway track.
category: H:Transportation and storage/49:Land transport and transport via pipelines/491:Transport via railways/4912:Freight rail transport

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Demand for diesel, locomotive, goods wagon and railway track from Indian rail transport statistics. Particulate, NOx, SOx and NMVOC emissions from EcoTransIT (2016) applying the emission factors most relevant to South African locomotives (44% non-regulated and 56% UIC II). All other emissions to air extrapolated from global dataset based on diesel consumption.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Data is representative of national freight rail for the 2016/2017 financial year
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Emissions to air (other than particulates, NOx, SOx and NMVOC) extrapolated from global dataset on the basis of diesel consumption.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Demand for diesel, locomotive, goods wagon and railway track from South African national rail transport statistics and representative of all rail freight movements in the reference year. Particulate, NOx, SOx and NMVOC emissions from EcoTransIT (2016) applying the emission factors most relevant to South African locomotives (non-regulated and UIC II).

flow.name: transport, freight train

exchanges.description: Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with lead emissions in these datasets are based on literature values from Jungbluth (Spielmann et al., 2007).                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with heavy metal emissions in these datasets applying literature values from an EEA document, based on an expert panel review. 
Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Calculated value for the demand of a goods wagon to fulfil one tonne.km of freight transport. Calculation based on the number of goods wagons (Transnet, 2016a) and the total tonne.kms transported in the year. Total tonne.kms for general freight was reported directly (Transnet, 2017), while tonne.kms for iron ore and coal export were calculated from the total tonnages transported (Transnet, 2017) and the average transport distance. Transport distance was averaged for 2009, 2010 and 2011 for iron ore exports and modelled by linear regression of 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2016 data for coal exports  (Transnet, 2016b; Transnet, 2011; Transnet, 2010).  A goods wagon lifetime of 40 years is assumed (Spielmann et al., 2007).                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   References: Transnet (2017) Transnet Integrated Report 2017; Transnet (2016a); Transnet Long Term Planning Framework 2016 - Rail Development Plan; Transnet (2016b); Transnet Long Term Planning Framework 2016 - Freight Demand Plan; Transnet (2011) Integrated Annual Report 2011; Transnet (2010) Integrated Annual Report 2010; Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.
EcoSpold01Location=RER

exchanges.description: Calculated value for the demand of a diesel locomotive to fulfil one tonne.km of diesel freight transport. Calculation based on the number of diesel locomotives (Transnet, 2016a) and the total tonne.kms transported by diesel locomotives in the year. The total tonne.kms transported by diesel locomotives was calculated using the fuel and electricity efficiency (Transnet, 2017a) and the total tonne.kms of rail freight for 2017. Total tonne.kms for general freight was reported directly (Transnet, 2017b), while tonne.kms for iron ore and coal export are calculated from the total tonnages transported (Transnet, 2017b) and the average transport distance. Transport distance was averaged for 2009, 2010 and 2011 for iron ore exports and modelled by linear regression of 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2016 data for coal exports  (Transnet, 2016b; Transnet, 2011; Transnet, 2010).  A locomotive lifetime of 40 years is assumed (Spielmann et al., 2007).                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   References: Transnet (2017a) Transnet Sustainability Report 2017; Transnet (2017b) Transnet Integrated Report 2017; Transnet (2016a); Transnet Long Term Planning Framework 2016 - Rail Development Plan; Transnet (2016b); Transnet Long Term Planning Framework 2016 - Freight Demand Plan; Transnet (2011) Integrated Annual Report 2011; Transnet (2010) Integrated Annual Report 2010; Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

exchanges.description: Particulate emissions from both abrasion and fuel combustion are considered.  Particulate emissions from the abrasion of railway tracks, wheels, brakes and overhead lines (1.17E-5) are taken from Spielmann et al. (2007).                                                                                                                                                                                   Particulate emissions from diesel use are calculated from particulate emission factors for locomotives following non-regulated and UIC II emissions standards available in EcoTransIT (2016) (g/kg diesel). It is assumed that 44% of South African locomotives meet non-regulated emission factors, while the remaining 56% meet UIC II emission standards (based on the tonne.kms transported by Class 43 diesel locomotives, as these are currently the only locomotives to meet UIC II emission standards in South Africa (TransportWorldAfrica, 2012). The tonne.kms transported by Class 43 versus other diesel locomotives is estimated from the number of Class 43 locomotives (Transnet (2016), the routes on which these locomotives operate (Creamer, 2012), the gross tonne.km performance of locomotives (Transnet, 2013; Transnet, 2017) and the ratio of gross to net tonn.kms (Transnet, 2017)). The breakdown of particulates into size fractions is based on the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004), with the global dataset derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007). In these datasets the particulate size distribution is assumed to match that of diesel locomotives without particulate filters, as presented by EU-Norm IIIa (Spielmann et al., 2007).                                                                                                                                                                                                        References: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland; EcoTransIT (2016) Ecological Transport Information Tool for Worldwide Transports - Methodology and Data Update; Transnet (2016) Long Term Planning Framework 2016 - Rail Development Plan; TransportWorldAfrica (2012) GE Transportation & MIC deliver reliable locomotives with high local content on-time. Available at: http://www.transportworldafrica.co.za/2012/06/28/ge-transportation-mic-deliver-reliable-locomotives-with-high-local-content-on-time/ (22 May 2018).; Creamer, T. (2012) Transnet boosts locomotive manufacturing capacity, confirms new order of 43 more GE units. Creamer Media's Engineering News. Available at: http://www.engineeringnews.co.za/article/transnet-boosts-loco-manufacturing-capacity-as-it-confirms-new-order-for-43-more-ge-units-2012-01-10/rep_id:4136.; Transnet (2013) Transnet Freight Rail Annual Integrated Report 2013. Transnet.; Transnet (2017) Transnet Freight Rail 2017. Transnet.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with emissions in these datasets based on Swiss heavy goods vehicle emissions in urban traffic conditions.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with emissions in these datasets based on Swiss heavy goods vehicle emissions in urban traffic conditions.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Diesel consumption includes diesel use for shunting and is calculated from total freight rail diesel usage and total tonne.kms transported using diesel locomotives (19% of total tonne.kms). The total diesel usage for diesel locomotives is calculated from total Transnet freight rail diesel usage (Transnet, 2017a), with the diesel usage for electric locomotive shunting subtracted. Diesel usage for electric locomotive shunting is calculated from total diesel usage for freight rail, the percentage of diesel used for shunting (19%) (personal communication with Transnet) and the percentage of freight transport using electric locomotives (81% of total tonne.kms). The total tonne.kms transported by diesel locomotives is calculated using the fuel and electricity efficiency (Transnet, 2017a) and the total tonne.kms of rail freight for 2017. Total tonne.kms for general freight is reported directly (Transnet, 2017b), while tonne.kms for iron ore and coal export are calculated from the total tonnages transported (Transnet, 2017b) and the average transport distance. Transport distance was averaged for 2009, 2010 and 2011 for iron ore exports and modelled by linear regression of 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2016 data for coal exports  (Transnet, 2016; Transnet, 2011; Transnet, 2010). A diesel density of 0.8 kg/L is assumed (SAPIA, 2008).                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 References: Transnet (2017a) Transnet Sustainability Report 2017; Transnet (2017b) Transnet Integrated Report 2017; Transnet (2016); Transnet Long Term Planning Framework 2016 - Freight Demand Plan; Transnet (2011) Integrated Annual Report 2011; Transnet (2010) Integrated Annual Report 2010; SAPIA (2008) Petrol and Diesel in South Africa and the impact on air quality.;  Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Particulate emissions from both abrasion and fuel combustion are considered.  Particulate emissions from the abrasion of railway tracks, wheels, brakes and overhead lines (1.63E-5) are taken from Spielmann et al. (2007).                                                                                                                                                                                   Particulate emissions from diesel use are calculated from particulate emission factors for locomotives following non-regulated and UIC II emissions standards available in EcoTransIT (2016) (g/kg diesel). It is assumed that 44% of South African locomotives meet non-regulated emission factors, while the remaining 56% meet UIC II emission standards (based on the tonne.kms transported by Class 43 diesel locomotives, as these are currently the only locomotives to meet UIC II emission standards in South Africa (TransportWorldAfrica, 2012). The tonne.kms transported by Class 43 versus other diesel locomotives is estimated from the number of Class 43 locomotives (Transnet (2016), the routes on which these locomotives operate (Creamer, 2012), the gross tonne.km performance of locomotives (Transnet, 2013; Transnet, 2017) and the ratio of gross to net tonn.kms (Transnet, 2017)). The breakdown of particulates into size fractions is based on the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004), with the global dataset derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007). In these datasets the particulate size distribution is assumed to match that of diesel locomotives without particulate filters, as presented by EU-Norm IIIa (Spielmann et al., 2007).                                                                                                                                                                                                        References: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland; EcoTransIT (2016) Ecological Transport Information Tool for Worldwide Transports - Methodology and Data Update; Transnet (2016) Long Term Planning Framework 2016 - Rail Development Plan; TransportWorldAfrica (2012) GE Transportation & MIC deliver reliable locomotives with high local content on-time. Transnet.; Transnet (2017) Transnet Freight Rail 2017. Transnet.

Calculated value for the demand of a locomotive to fulfil one tonne.km of diesel freight transport. Calculation based on the number of diesel locomotives (Transnet, 2016a) and the total tonne.kms transported by diesel locomotives in the year. The total tonne.kms transported by diesel locomotives was calculated using the fuel and electricity efficiency (Transnet, 2017a) and the total tonne.kms of rail freight for 2017. Total tonne.kms for general freight was reported directly (Transnet, 2017b), while tonne.kms for iron ore and coal export are calculated from the total tonnages transported (Transnet, 2017b) and the average transport distance. Transport distance was averaged for 2009, 2010 and 2011 for iron ore exports and modelled by linear regression of 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2016 data for coal exports  (Transnet, 2016b; Transnet, 2011; Transnet, 2010).  A locomotive lifetime of 40 years is assumed (Spielmann et al., 2007). exchanges.description:
Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with heavy metal emissions in these datasets applying literature values from an EEA document, based on an expert panel review. 
Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with heavy metal emissions in these datasets applying literature values from an EEA document, based on an expert panel review. 
Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with emissions in these datasets based on Swiss heavy goods vehicle emissions in urban traffic conditions.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

NMVOC emissions are calculated from hydrocarbon emission factors for locomotives following UIC I and UIC II emissions standards available in EcoTransIT (2016) (g/kg diesel), corrected for methane emissions. It is assumed that 44% of South African locomotives meet non-regulated emission factors, while the remaining 56% meet UIC II emission standards (based on the tonne.kms transported by Class 43 diesel locomotives, as these are currently the only locomotives to meet UIC II emission standards in South Africa (TransportWorldAfrica, 2012). The tonne.kms transported by Class 43 versus other diesel locomotives is estimated from the number of Class 43 locomotives (Transnet (2016), the routes on which these locomotives operate (Creamer, 2012), the gross tonne.km performance of locomotives (Transnet, 2013; Transnet, 2017) and the ratio of gross to net tonn.kms (Transnet, 2017)). The breakdown of particulates into size fractions is based on the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004), with the global dataset derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007). In these datasets the particulate size distribution is assumed to match that of diesel locomotives without particulate filters, as presented by EU-Norm IIIa (Spielmann et al., 2007).                                                                                                                                                                                                        References: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland; EcoTransIT (2016) Ecological Transport Information Tool for Worldwide Transports - Methodology and Data Update; Transnet (2016) Long Term Planning Framework 2016 - Rail Development Plan; TransportWorldAfrica (2012) GE Transportation & MIC deliver reliable locomotives with high local content on-time. Available at: http://www.transportworldafrica.co.za/2012/06/28/ge-transportation-mic-deliver-reliable-locomotives-with-high-local-content-on-time/ (22 May 2018).; Creamer, T. (2012) Transnet boosts locomotive manufacturing capacity, confirms new order of 43 more GE units. Creamer Media's Engineering News. Available at: http://www.engineeringnews.co.za/article/transnet-boosts-loco-manufacturing-capacity-as-it-confirms-new-order-for-43-more-ge-units-2012-01-10/rep_id:4136.; Transnet (2013) Transnet Freight Rail Annual Integrated Report 2013. Transnet.; Transnet (2017) Transnet Freight Rail 2017. Transnet.

Particulate emissions are calculated from particulate emission factors for locomotives following non-regulated and UIC II emissions standards available in EcoTransIT (2016) (g/kg diesel). It is assumed that 44% of South African locomotives meet non-regulated emission factors, while the remaining 56% meet UIC II emission standards (based on the tonne.kms transported by Class 43 diesel locomotives, as these are currently the only locomotives to meet UIC II emission standards in South Africa (TransportWorldAfrica, 2012). The tonne.kms transported by Class 43 versus other diesel locomotives is estimated from the number of Class 43 locomotives (Transnet (2016), the routes on which these locomotives operate (Creamer, 2012), the gross tonne.km performance of locomotives (Transnet, 2013; Transnet, 2017) and the ratio of gross to net tonn.kms (Transnet, 2017)). The breakdown of particulates into size fractions is based on the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004), with the global dataset derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007). In these datasets the particulate size distribution is assumed to match that of diesel locomotives without particulate filters, as presented by EU-Norm IIIa (Spielmann et al., 2007).                                                                                                                                                                                                        References: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland; EcoTransIT (2016) Ecological Transport Information Tool for Worldwide Transports - Methodology and Data Update; Transnet (2016) Long Term Planning Framework 2016 - Rail Development Plan; TransportWorldAfrica (2012) GE Transportation & MIC deliver reliable locomotives with high local content on-time. Available at: http://www.transportworldafrica.co.za/2012/06/28/ge-transportation-mic-deliver-reliable-locomotives-with-high-local-content-on-time/ (22 May 2018).; Creamer, T. (2012) Transnet boosts locomotive manufacturing capacity, confirms new order of 43 more GE units. Creamer Media's Engineering News. Available at: http://www.engineeringnews.co.za/article/transnet-boosts-loco-manufacturing-capacity-as-it-confirms-new-order-for-43-more-ge-units-2012-01-10/rep_id:4136.; Transnet (2013) Transnet Freight Rail Annual Integrated Report 2013. Transnet.; Transnet (2017) Transnet Freight Rail 2017. Transnet.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with carbon dioxide emissions in these datasets calculated assuming that all carbon in the fuel is converted to carbon dioxide. The emission index is therefore 3,146 g/kg (Spielmann et al., 2007).   
Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Sulphur dioxide emissions are calculated from diesel usage and assuming that all sulphur in the fuel is converted to sulphur dioxide (Spielmann et al., 2007). South Africa currently uses diesel with a sulphur content of 500 ppm (SAPIA, 2015), resulting in an emission index of 10 g/kg.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland; SAPIA (2015) Cleaner Fuels II, Available at: http://www.sapia.org.za/key-issues/cleaner-fuels-ii (22 May 2018).

Nitrogen oxide emissions are calculated from NOx emission factors for locomotives following UIC I and UIC II emissions standards available in EcoTransIT (2016) (g/kg diesel).  It is assumed that 44% of South African locomotives meet non-regulated emission factors, while the remaining 56% meet UIC II emission standards (based on the tonne.kms transported by Class 43 diesel locomotives, as these are currently the only locomotives to meet UIC II emission standards in South Africa (TransportWorldAfrica, 2012). The tonne.kms transported by Class 43 versus other diesel locomotives is estimated from the number of Class 43 locomotives (Transnet (2016), the routes on which these locomotives operate (Creamer, 2012), the gross tonne.km performance of locomotives (Transnet, 2013; Transnet, 2017) and the ratio of gross to net tonn.kms (Transnet, 2017)). The breakdown of particulates into size fractions is based on the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004), with the global dataset derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007). In these datasets the particulate size distribution is assumed to match that of diesel locomotives without particulate filters, as presented by EU-Norm IIIa (Spielmann et al., 2007).                                                                                                                                                                                                        References: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland; EcoTransIT (2016) Ecological Transport Information Tool for Worldwide Transports - Methodology and Data Update; Transnet (2016) Long Term Planning Framework 2016 - Rail Development Plan; TransportWorldAfrica (2012) GE Transportation & MIC deliver reliable locomotives with high local content on-time. Available at: http://www.transportworldafrica.co.za/2012/06/28/ge-transportation-mic-deliver-reliable-locomotives-with-high-local-content-on-time/ (22 May 2018).; Creamer, T. (2012) Transnet boosts locomotive manufacturing capacity, confirms new order of 43 more GE units. Creamer Media's Engineering News. Available at: http://www.engineeringnews.co.za/article/transnet-boosts-loco-manufacturing-capacity-as-it-confirms-new-order-for-43-more-ge-units-2012-01-10/rep_id:4136.; Transnet (2013) Transnet Freight Rail Annual Integrated Report 2013. Transnet.; Transnet (2017) Transnet Freight Rail 2017. Transnet.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with emissions in these datasets based on Swiss heavy goods vehicle emissions in urban traffic conditions.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with heavy metal emissions in these datasets applying literature values from an EEA document, based on an expert panel review. 
Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with carbon monoxide emissions in these datasets based on a literature study on shunting specific emissions indices. 
Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Calculated value for the demand of railway track to fulfil one tonne.km of diesel freight transport. Calculation based on total two-way railway track length (Transnet, 2016b) and the total tonne.kms transported by diesel locomotives in the year. The total tonne.kms transported by diesel locomotives was calculated using the fuel and electricity efficiency (Transnet, 2017a) and the total tonne.kms of rail freight for 2017. Total tonne.kms for general freight was reported directly (Transnet, 2017b), while tonne.kms for iron ore and coal export were calculated from the total tonnages transported (Transnet, 2017b) and the average transport distance. Transport distance was averaged for 2009, 2010 and 2011 for iron ore exports and modelled by linear regression of 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2016 data for coal exports  (Transnet, 2016b; Transnet, 2011; Transnet, 2010).                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 References: Transnet (2017a) Transnet Sustainability Report 2017; Transnet (2017b) Transnet Integrated Report 2017; Transnet (2016a); Transnet Long Term Planning Framework 2016 - Rail Development Plan; Transnet (2016b); Transnet Long Term Planning Framework 2016 - Freight Demand Plan; Transnet (2011) Integrated Annual Report 2011; Transnet (2010) Integrated Annual Report 2010; Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.
EcoSpold01Location=CH
